page.title: 09Life of a Chorister
page.content: When you are a{chorister}you have a long hard day. School begins at 0830. As well as the usual academic subjects, music lessons and choir practice have to be fitted in. The day ends with the sung service of Evensong and we finally go home at 1800. The day occasionally includes a special{service}such as Ascension Day or someone's funeral. Our busiest days are Good Friday, with the St. Matthew's Passion, and Christmas, which is so busy that no-one opens presents till Boxing Day. At services we wear red cassocks, white surpices and white ruffs. We are paid 4p per service and we are fined 20p for misbehaving. Being a chorister has its advantages. On our tour to U.S.A. we got into Disneyland free, because we gave a concert there of Scottish songs.
